The area covers the southern part including Orango and Orangozinho along with the western islands and the marine portion up to around 150 to 200 km within the Bijagos Archipelago (much of its Bijagos portion of the continental shelf) up to the areas mainly 2,000 meters deep outside the continental shelf. The park is administered by : Instituto da Biodiversidade e das Áreas Protegidas da Guiné-Bissau (Biodiversity Institute and Protected Areas of Guinea-Bissau).

Perth Canyon
Perth Canyon is a submarine canyon located on the edge of the continental shelf off the coast of Perth, Western Australia, approximately 22 km west of Rottnest Island. It was carved by the Swan River, probably before the Tertiary, when this part of the continental shelf was above sea level. It is an average of 1.5 km deep and 15 km across, making it similar in dimension to the Grand Canyon.

Monique Gladding
Monique Gladding (born 17 June 1981 in Durban, South Africa) is a South African-born British diver. She competed for Great Britain in the 10 metre platform event at the 2012 Summer Olympics.

Corocoro United Copper Mines
The Corocoro United Copper Mines, Ltd. was the largest copper mine in Bolivia, an honor previously held by Compania Corocoro de Bolivia. The corporate office was at 151 Finsbury Pavement House, London, England, while the mine office was at Coro Coro, Bolivia. It was organized August 6, 1909 under the laws of Great Britain. The lands included 515 claims in the Coro Coro district. The principal mines were the Wisk'achani, formerly owned by J. K. Child & Co., Ltd.; the Santa Rosa, formerly owned by Carreras Hermanos; and the Guallatiri, formerly owned by the Succession Noel Berthin. The mines were opened on two successive conglomerate strata of different geological horizons, and similar only in their origin and cupriferous nature. The mines are believed to have been worked by the Incas. The nearest water supply was the Rio Desaguadero, 14 miles away, down which the copper was shipped by way of Puerto de Desaguadero, and from there to Mollendo, Chile, for export to Europe.

The Women's Peace Crusade
The Women's Peace Crusade was a grass-roots socialist movement that spread across Great Britain between 1916 and 1918. Its central aim was to spread a 'people's peace', which was defined as a negotiated end to the First World War without any annexations or indemnities. The movement was first established in Glasgow in July 1916, and officially launched on 10 June 1917. It later spread across Great Britain, with demonstrations taking place in Leeds, Bradford, Leicester, Birmingham and Lancashire. Although it gathered a substantial following, the Women's Peace Crusade faced opposition from both the government and police, with members being arrested and reportedly threatened.

Tim Cranston
Tim Cranston (born 13 December 1962 in Halifax, Nova Scotia) is a retired professional ice hockey player who holds dual Canadian and British nationality. He played in Europe between 1985 and 1999 except for one game in the 1986–87 season played in the American Hockey League. He was also a member of the Great Britain national ice hockey team between 1993 and 1997. Whilst living in the United Kingdom, Cranston was the founding chairman of the British Ice Hockey Player's Association (GB). Currently living in Halifax, Nova Scotia, Cranston is working as a sports agent and lawyer for the sports and entertainment industries. He was inducted into the British Ice Hockey Hall of Fame in 2010.

This area was probably a rich habitat with human habitation in the Mesolithic period, but it was gradually reduced to low-lying islands before its final submergence, possibly following a tsunami caused by the Storegga Slide.

The submergence of landmasses between Great Britain and continental Europe around 6200 BCE was likely caused by the Storegga Slide, one of the largest known landslides, which occurred under water at the edge of Norway's continental shelf in the Norwegian Sea. This event involved an estimated 290 km length of coastal shelf, with a total volume of 3500 km3 of debris, causing a very large tsunami in the North Atlantic Ocean. This geological event led to the flooding of Doggerland, an area that connected Great Britain to continental Europe during and after the last glacial period. The rising sea levels gradually reduced Doggerland to low-lying islands before its final submergence, possibly following the tsunami caused by the Storegga Slide. This event had significant geological and environmental impacts on the region, leading to the formation of the North Sea as a marginal sea of the Atlantic Ocean.

The known massive landslides along the continental shelf of Europe include the Storegga Slide, which occurred in the Norwegian Sea and caused a large tsunami in the North Atlantic Ocean. Additionally, the Tyra West – F3 pipeline facilitates the export of Danish gas into North West Europe, and the Gassco company operates natural gas pipes transporting gas from the Norwegian continental shelf to Continental Europe and Great Britain.

Outside of Europe, the Siberian Shelf is the largest continental shelf on Earth, extending from the continent of Eurasia into the Arctic Ocean. The Pacific Ocean Shelf Tracking Project researches the behavior of marine animals using ocean telemetry and data management systems, and the NOGAT Pipeline System connects the Dutch continental shelf with an onshore gas plant and terminal at Den Helder, the Netherlands.

Other notable features include the Orango Islands National Park in Guinea-Bissau, which covers both terrestrial and marine areas, and the Perth Canyon, a submarine canyon located on the edge of the continental shelf off the coast of Perth, Western Australia.
